item.title: Basement Jaxx's favourite tracks
item.description:
The seasoned Brixton punk garage party-starters empty the contents of their psychic record bag

The track we'll be opening our next DJ set with
Basement Jaxx: People Of Planet Earth

This features a church organ piece composed by Joe Benjamin, a 70-year-old Bermudan now living in Brixton. Who knows, you might hear it on our new album…

The track we always play to rescue a dancefloor
APDW Vs Basement Jaxx: Red Alert (remix)

We've been playing this remix by Analog People In A Digital World for a while. It'll be released early next year.

The track that's been unfairly slept on this year
Michel Cleis: Mir A Nero

He had a big track with La Mezcla a few years ago. Mir A Nero is similarly percussive, melodic, and just has a great feel.

The track we'd play to show off our eclectic tastes

Felix: Alim Qasimov: Bayati Shiraz

A classical singer from Azerbaijan, this is one of my newest purchases.

Simon: Marco Benevento: Wolf Trap

I tune into random radio stations online. I heard this on a jazz station from New Orleans, went to the website, found the tracklisting and bought the album. The world is small.

The track that got us out of bed this morning
Baauer: Harlem Shake

A big "trap" track - heavy bass, 808 snares, speeding hats and a hooky noise.

The best track by our favourite new artist
Disclosure: What's In Your Head

Love what these guys are doing. Good old-fashioned deep house, 2012 style.

The track we'd play at sunset in Ibiza
Basement Jaxx Vs Metropole Orkest: Raindrops

In 2011, we collaborated with conductor/arranger Jules Buckley and the 70-piece Metropole Orkest to reinterpret our back catalogue for an album and two shows at the Barbican. This is one of our favourites.

The track we'd play at our auntie's wedding
Boom Pam: Wedding Song

A knees-up track we discovered when we released the Gypsy Beats And Balkan Bangers compilation. Boom Pam are actually from Israel but they play a mix of Balkan and Mediterranean music.

The ideal festival track
Queen: Bohemian Rhapsody (Schizofonics remix)

A classic electro-ish rework which always goes down a treat. There's also a brass band version we play – people sing the whole thing, start to finish. It brings everyone together and it's a little break from the boom boom.

Basement Jaxx play Saturday Sessions @ Ministry Of Sound, SE1, Sat

item.title: This week's new theatre
item.description:
Heidi – A Goat's Tale | Cinderellas | Arabian Nights | Pantos for adults | The Importance Of Being Earnest | The Last March

Heidi - A Goat's Tale, Bath

Director Lee Lyford always delivers a terrific Christmas show in the delicious Egg Theatre. Based on Johanna Spyri's much-loved but rather dated story of a girl who goes to live in the Alps and befriends a goatherd and a disabled child, this script by Andrew Pollard takes a clever comic approach. It's one that's tried and tested: the show was first produced at the Stephen Joseph Theatre in Scarborough in 2008 and received a Best Children's Play nomination in the TMA awards. With the story told through the eyes of the goats, it should entertain modern audiences.

Egg Theatre, Sat to 13 Jan

Lyn Gardner

Cinderellas, London

Cinderella certainly seems to be the panto of choice this year, with plenty of variety on offer. The most subversive will be Midnight's Pumpkin, at the BAC, SW11 (to 13 Jan), which will get the audience donning dancing shoes to impress Prince Charming. At London's newest theatre, the St James, SW1 (to 26 Jan), Cinderella: A Fairytale is given a sweet storytelling spin by Tobacco Factory Theatre as a bullied Cinders finds solace in woodland birds. Cinderella The Midnight Princess at the Rose Theatre, Kingston (to 6 Jan) offers the familiar ingredients, though Charles Way's adaptation adds a struggling court composer called Mozart; while Cinderella (Lyric Hammersmith, W6, to 5 Jan) has Mel Giedroyc as the wicked stepmother.

Mark Cook

Arabian Nights, Salford

Dominic Cooke's adaptation graced the Young Vic more than a decade ago and these retellings of familiar stories such as Sinbad The Sailor, Ali Baba And The Forty Thieves and The Story Of The Little Beggar have proved popular ever since. Indeed, there are a couple more adaptations in London this winter. In truth, rather like Carol Ann Duffy's Grimm Tales, the power of any revival is in the staging and the discovery of a theatrical language to match the simple power of the stories themselves. What really gives these tales – which encompass the miraculous and the ribald – their emotional punch is the clever framing device: the storyteller is new bride Shahrazad, who is telling the stories to stay alive. She will only keep her head if her husband wants to hear the next story – there's something genuinely at stake.

The Lowry, to 12 Jan

LG

Pantos for adults, London

One pantomime this year boasts a historic farewell: positively the final appearance of Lily Savage – or so says one Paul O'Grady of his "blonde bombsite" alter ego – in Aladdin: A Wish Come True as Widow Twankey at The 02, SE10 (to 5 Jan). The title role is played by Jon Lee (pictured), ex of S Club 7 but more recently a star of Les Misérables and Jersey Boys. More camp goings-on can be found in Get Aladdin at the Landor Theatre, SW9 (to 6 Jan). It's from Above The Stag, so expect more innuendo than you can poke a festive sausage at; it's most definitely not for the kiddies. In a similar, er, vein, at the Leicester Square Theatre, WC2 (to 20 Jan), there's also Dick! which follows the journey of hero Dick and his cat Dave as they try to make their way in old London town. Characters include Queen Runt, Alice and Sofondo Cox. Ridiculously rude adult fun.

MC

The Importance Of Being Earnest, Scarborough

George Bernard Shaw did not care much for Oscar Wilde's comedy of manners. He declared that its convoluted plot and witty dialogue "leave me with a sense of having wasted my evening". You can't please everyone, but this play has proved considerably more enduring with audiences than most of Shaw's plays. It makes a welcome reappearance in Scarborough in this revival by Chris Monks in which the tale of young love, lost babies and handbags should provide much-needed entertainment for those who find most festive theatre a bit of a bore. Wilde's play can sparkle as brightly as any Christmas tree.

Stephen Joseph Theatre, Tue to 5 Jan

LG

The Last March, Exeter

It's been a good year for Exeter theatre with the successful delivery of a first project by the new Kaleider initiative, which will deliver productions in non-theatre spaces to the city over the next three years, plus the feeling that the city's cosy Bikeshed space is beginning to make a real impact as it encourages young companies from the region and beyond. Tinder hails from Portsmouth and will be offering an alternative Christmas show with this tragicomic retelling of the story of Captain Scott and his doomed attempt to beat the Norwegian explorer, Admundsen, to the South Pole. Expect lots of snow but very little tinsel. The company takes a comic approach to a story of heroism, the foolhardy and the very English, all told with pots of tea and absolutely no huskies.

The Bikeshed Theatre, Tue to 12 Jan

LG

item.title: Christmas dance round-up
item.description:
Royal Ballet | Legacy The Return | The Outsider

There may be at least half a dozen Nutcrackers playing over the festive season but dance fans can find alternatives if they look. The Royal Ballet is making an interesting break with tradition by opening a new triple bill three days before Christmas (Royal Opera House, WC2, 22 Dec to 11 Jan), offering its audiences a grown-up alternative to sugary magic and snowflakes. The centrepiece is Jerome Robbins's rarely seen ballet In The Night, a trio of subtly nuanced romantic, erotic duets set to the music of Chopin. Dream casting includes Sarah Lamb, Marianela Nú��ez and Alina Cojocaru. Opening the evening is a revival of Mikhail Fokine's exotic fairytale The Firebird, and concluding it is Raymonda Act III (top), a ballet of exemplary imperial crackle with Cojocaru and Zenaida Yanowsky alternating in the ballerina role.

At the other end of the dance spectrum is Legacy The Return, the latest show by hip-hop company Boy Blue (Jerwood DanceHouse, Ipswich, to 23 Dec). It advertises itself as a family-friendly spectacle and is directed by choreographers Kenrick Sandy and Michael Asante. Finally, tonight sees the John Scott Dance Company perform Kyle Abraham's group piece The Outsider for Dance Ireland (Project Arts Centre, Dublin). Abraham himself dances two solos including an extract from Live! The Realist MC which re-imagines Pinocchio as a B-boy.

item.title: This week's new events
item.description:
Burning The Clocks | Montol Eve | Festival Of The Apocalypse | Out & about

Burning The Clocks, Brighton

It might sound like some idle anarchist scheme to make sure we all fail to get up of a morning, but this colourful Brighton parade is actually a way for locals to mark the winter solstice, with lanterns being lit and then left to burn on the beach. Founded in 1995, the non-commercial festival draws on winter festivals past, with around 2,000 lantern-bearing revellers making their way through the city's streets and down to the sea. The procession closes with fireworks and fancy pyrotechnics, as spectators watch from the pebbles.

North Street to Madeira Drive, Fri

Iain Aitch

Montol Eve, Penzance

Reviving an ancient local tradition, this relatively new festival marks the death and rebirth of the sun with burning lanterns set atop high points, rivers of fire and, erm, a tea dance. The festival, which celebrates custom and history yet does not take itself too seriously, runs from morning until night, with craft events and bands building up to a late-night torchlit procession through the streets of Penzance. The Turkey Rhubarb Guise Band and Penzance Youth String Orchestra provide the musical entertainment, with fancy dress, Christmas singalongs and dancing. You may even become mayor for the evening if you dress right and get lucky.

St John's Hall, Fri

IA

Festival Of The Apocalypse, Gateshead

As mentioned elsewhere in this issue, we're all done for come Friday. So to bid this world ta-ra, the BALTIC is throwing a weekend of twilight talks and prophetic performances. Physicist David Korowicz will explore how we can "wisely and creatively adapt" to our post-growth age, while trombonist John Kenny casts off the old days and heralds the new dawn with his sunrise and sunset opuses on the carnyx (it's an iron-age battle horn). Meanwhile, ongoing installation The Encampment Of Eternal Hope features Triffid-esque tents and Survival Exercise Classes, and will last into the new year – assuming there is one.

BALTIC, Fri and 22 Dec

Colette Bernhardt

Out & about

Christkindlmarkt, Leeds, Sat & Sun

Leeds's answer to Manchester's German Christmas Market shuts up shop after this weekend, so this is a last chance to combine Bavarian grub, booze and last-minute gift buying.

Millennium Square

Christmas Carolling, Manchester, Mon

This is a chance to belt out classics like The First Noël and Good King Wenceslas in the company of Russell Watson.

Bridgewater Hall

A Christmas Celebration, London, Wed & Thu

The award-winning Westminster Cathedral Choir will be singing classic Christmas songs with celebrity readers including Baroness Warsi and Peep Show's Alan Johnson AKA Patterson Joseph.

Westminster Cathedral, SW1

Winter Ice Rink, Plymouth, to 24 Feb

Special events for kids, skating lessons for all abilities, plus the potentially messy Breakfast And Skate With Santa.

The Piazza

item.title: From the archive, 15 December 1981: Israelis vote to annex Golan Heights
item.description:
Last night's annexation of the Golan Heights removes all prospect of a territorial compromise in any future peace negotiations between Israel and Syria

Israel last night annexed the Golan Heights, captured from Syria in the Six-day War of June 1967. The measure removes all prospect of a territorial compromise in any future peace negotiation. Annexation of the Heights, where 6,600 Jews live in 31 settlements, will be popular with the overwhelming majority of Israelis.

Israel's annexation in all but name of the Golan Heights is Mr Begin's way of poking a sharp stick in the eye of President Assad of Syria when the President's other eye is being poked by the Muslim Brotherhood. The move will have wide support in Israel, first because the Heights are deemed essential to the security of the settlements in the valley below, and second because Mr Assad is thus shown the penalty of not entering into peace negotiations (not that he would get the Heights back if he did).

Syria and the Soviet Union do not have the type of treaty which regards an attack on one as an attack on the other, but their treaty of October 1980 is enough to ensure that the stick is poked in Mr Brezhnev's eye as well. The two countries resolved that "in cases of the emergence of situations jeopardising peace or the security of one of the parties" they would "enter without delay into contact with each other with a view to cooperating in order to remove the threat." Entering without delay is not the same as mounting an attack on Israel. Nor can a change in notional status which leaves things unmoved on the ground in itself jeopardise the security of Syria. Nonetheless the Israeli Government has clearly decided to keep up the momentum allowed to it by the collapse of comprehensive peace moves from Europe and Riyadh, and the tension in the region is therefore fractionally increased.

Any Israeli government has a diverse constituency to satisfy and Mr Begin's is no exception. The withdrawal from Sinai due in April has antagonised the Gush Emunim and other nationalist groups who have threatened physically to obstruct it. Annexation of the Golan may therefore have been designed partly as an emollient to Sinai settlers. Until President Mubarak has retrieved his territory he in turn will not wish to prejudice the deal by strenuous opposition to the Golan annexation.

What the annexation does is to signal Israel's commitment to its own terms and only its own terms for securing peace. They include the effective control of all the territory seized in 1967 with the exception of the Sinai desert. The Sinai withdrawal is unpopular even with members of the Government, but as the price of making peace with Israel it is just acceptable. But were President Assad to make the journey to the Knesset himself he would not get the Golan Heights: and the stark truth is that they are more important defensively to Israel than they are agriculturally to him.

item.title: Newtown shooting: Google adds solitary white candle to US homepage
item.description:
Move appears to be the first time site's popular doodle feature has been used to respond to a breaking news story

Google added a small, glowing candle to its main search page after news emerged of the school shooting in the US.

When users hover a cursor over the icon, a text box appears that says: "Our hearts are with the families and community of Newtown, Connecticut."

According to the site, more than 5 million people searched Ryan Lanza, the person incorrectly identified as the suspected shooter, on Friday. The next most popular search was CNN, with one-fifth as many searches at more than 1 million.

A scan of the official doodle blog shows that this appears to be the first time Google has deployed a breaking news icon in this way. The Google doodle began 12 years ago.

Usually, Google doodles appear in place of the search engine's logo. This time, the emblem appears below the search box.

Google is the most popular website in the world and Google Doodles usually signify major historical milestones and anniversaries.

The previous Google doodle appeared on Monday – a picture to celebrate the 197th birthday of Ada King, the Countess of Lovelace, a woman often credited with being the first computer programmer.

A list of most popular doodles was released on Wednesday, with interactive games for the Olympics and playable animation for Valentine's Day.
